Title.evidence: This randomised controlled trial aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of behaviour change technique-based interventions on daily physical activity and clinical outcomes in individuals with intermittent claudication.

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised to either a behaviour change technique-based intervention group or a control group.

Participants.evidence: Participants were randomised to either a behaviour change technique-based intervention group or a control group.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to either a behaviour change technique-based intervention group or a control group.

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of behaviour change technique-based interventions on daily physical activity and clinical outcomes in individuals with intermittent claudication.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the change in daily physical activity, measured in steps per day, over a short-term period (<6 months) and maintenance period (>6 months).

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was conducted using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised, with 100 in each group, between January 2020 and June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised, with 100 in each group, between January 2020 and June 2021.

Result_Outcome.evidence: In the short term, the intervention group showed a significant increase in daily physical activity (standardised mean difference = 0.20, 95% CI 0.07 to 0.33, ~473 steps/day) compared to the control group.

Funding.evidence: FUNDING: National Institute for Health and Care Research (NIHR) Health Technology Assessment programme (NIHR award ref: NIHR130664).
